## ModulesOptions interface

Css modules processing options.

<b>Signature:</b>

```typescript
export interface ModulesOptions 
```

## Properties

|  Property | Type | Description |
|  --- | --- | --- |
|  [attachOriginalClassName?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.attachoriginalclassname.md) | boolean | <i>(Optional)</i> If you want to still use the original class name next to local one. Default false. |
|  [exportGlobals?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.exportglobals.md) | boolean | <i>(Optional)</i> If you need to export global names via the module object along with the local ones, add the exportGlobals option. |
|  [generateScopedName?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.generatescopedname.md) | string \| ((name: string, filename: string, css: string) =&gt; string) | <i>(Optional)</i> To generate custom classes, use the generateScopedName callback, or just pass an interpolated string to the generateScopedName option: <code>generateScopedName: &quot;[name]__[local]___[hash:base64:5]&quot;</code> |
|  [globalModulePaths?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.globalmodulepaths.md) | Array&lt;string \| RegExp&gt; | <i>(Optional)</i> To define paths for global modules, use the globalModulePaths option. It is an array with regular expressions defining the paths: |
|  [hashPrefix?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.hashprefix.md) | string | <i>(Optional)</i> It's possible to add custom hash to generate more unique classes using the hashPrefix option. |
|  [localsConvention?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.localsconvention.md) | 'camelCase' \| 'camelCaseOnly' \| 'dashes' \| 'dashesOnly' \| ((originalClassName: string, generatedClassName: string, inputFile: string) =&gt; string) | <i>(Optional)</i> Style of exported classnames. |
|  [scopeBehaviour?](./postcss-es-modules.modulesoptions.scopebehaviour.md) | 'global' \| 'local' | <i>(Optional)</i> By default, the plugin assumes that all the classes are local. You can change this behaviour using the scopeBehaviour option. |
